title: Did the King visit different parts of Medieval England regularly? Was his face instantly recognisable by most peasants? - Quora

response.answer_text: Medieval monarchs regularly “progressed” around at least parts of their kingdom. The king's court is a term that describes the king's council and household, and the court travelled with the king wherever he went. He travelled at least partly simply to maintain his position as ruler. His travels allowed him to see first-hand what was happening in his kingdom (though medieval kings of England rarely, if ever, travelled to the north of England unless pursuing a war with the Scots). A king would spend much of his time in three social settings: one where he was seen by and interacted with the general public, one where he would be with his relatives and courtiers, and finally when he was on his own (although with servants nearby). Much of his role would be to appear among commoners as well as in his court. One very important role of the crown was to ensure justice. Until the reign of Henry II (1154-89), royal justice was administered wherever the King happened to be, but under Henry, a royal ordinance decreed that, for the convenience of litigants, five judges should sit in a certain place rather than travel with the King. From 1178 this place was Westminster Hall for three of the courts of law (Common Pleas, King's Bench, and Chancery) while the Exchequer sat next door. From that time, even though royal progresses continued, it is possible to think of the royal capital as being Westminster (not, note, London). Coinage ensured that the king’s face was known to those of his subjects who did not have an opportunity to see him in the flesh.  A coin of Richard II (1367 – 1400). Whether you consider this an accurate portrait or not depends.  This portrait of him suggests the coin image is reasonably accurate.  His tomb effigy in Westminster Abbey (he was, of course, older then than in either the portrait or on the coinage image) also suggests the coin’s image was reasonably accurate. OR: you could take at face value the statement made by the Pythons in their film of the Holy Grail. “Who’s that there?” says the first filthy peasant. “Dunno. Must be the king,” says second filthy peasant. “Why?” asks the first filthy peasant. “He hasn’t got shit all over him,” replies the second filthy peasant.  How to spot a medieval monarch, by the Pythons.

The King visited different parts of England at intervals, but not regularly. He didn’t have a standard route or schedule. It depended on what else was going on in the world. Many of the medieval kings were involved in wars in France that took them away for months at a time, and they didn’t travel in winter—the roads were a quagmire. But they did travel around “on progress” to dispense justice and to be seen. The king’s face would not have been instantly recognizable to most peasants, only to those peasants who were lucky enough to see him as he passed down the road. However, the middle class—the townspeople—would have had a better idea of who he was because kings spent longer in towns than they did in the countryside. But many people in out-of-the-way places (Cornwall, for instance) would never have seen him in their entire lives.
